newsitem.title: THAILAND: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - May 30.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - May 30.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Thai press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The prime minister and army chief have allowed Burma to dredge the Moei River in Tak province in a deal in which Rangoon agrees to open the friendship bridge. The standoff between Thai and Burmese forces at the dredging site, which was settled yesterday, comes about because field military officers are not informed of the agreement. (BANGKOK POST)

- The influential tycoon's son accused of shooting a man in a pub is warned to surrender to the police or risk decisive action. The warning to Suksant, or Man, Kong-udom, is issued by commander of south Bangkok police, after the Interior Ministry issued a warrant for his arrest. Man is accused of shooting and assaulting Assadamongkol Tantemsap, a nephew of the Thai ambassador to Beijing, at the pub early on Tuesday. (BANGKOK POST) (THE NATION)

- Growing public criticism has prompted 30 democracy groups to make clear their stand by announcing support for the draft charter. The 30 organisations resolved at a meeting yesterday to back the draft. But they also want charter writers to heed their calls for the new constitution to give people full power to inspect the state's use of power, and to truly participate in running the country. (BANGKOK POST)

- Du Pont (USA) has put Thailand on top of its list of potential production bases in Southeast Asia, Du Pont (Thailand) president says. The company has plans to invest 2.5 billion baht in three petrochemical and chemical industrial projects in the region. (BUSINESS DAY)

- Industry Minister Korn Dabaransi plans to ask the Cabinet to urgently reverse the country's commitments under the AFTA agreement and withdraw petrochemical products from the ASEAN accelerated tariff reduction programme. Korn says he wants to save Thai petrochemical producers from being unjustly affected by an influx of Singaporean, Malaysian and Indonesian imports as a result of AFTA, which seeks to bring down tariff barriers between ASEAN members on manufactured goods. (THE NATION)

- Exxon Corp, one of the world's largest energy and petroleum concerns, is poised to build an aromatics complex in Thailand for US$400 million. Preparations are geared toward starting construction this October, with the final go-ahead due in a few months. (BANGKOK POST)
